Name: Afidopyropen
Description: Afidopyropen is an organic heterotetracyclic compound that is 1,3,4,4a,5,6,6a,12,12a,12b-decahydro-2H,11H-benzo[f]pyrano[4,3-b]chromen-11-one which is substituted by methyl groups at positions 4, 6a, and 12b; hydroxy groups at positions 3, 6, and 9; and a cyclopropycarbonyloxymethyl group and a cyclopropylcarbonyloxy group at positions 17 and 18 respectively, and a pyridin-3-yl group at position 14 (the (3S,4R,4aR,6S,6aS,12R,12aS,12bS stereoisomer). It is an insecticide that is effective against sucking insects on fruit, vegetables and nuts. It has a role as an insecticide, an agrochemical and a TRPV channel modulator. It is a cyclopropanecarboxylate ester, a member of pyridines, an organic heterotetracyclic compound and a secondary alcohol.

plant_translocations.content: Novel pesticides, broflanilide (BFI), afidopyropen (ADP), and flupyradifurone (FPO), have gained widespread usage but their uptake, translocation, and residual distribution in plants have remained unclear. To address this, mustard field trials and hydroponic experiments were conducted to investigate the residues distribution, uptake, and translocation of these pesticides. Field results indicated that the residues of BFI, ADP, and FPO in mustard plants were in the range of 0.001-1.87 mg/kg within 0-21 days and dissipated rapidly (half-lives of 5.2-11.3 days). FPO residues were predominantly distributed in cell-soluble fractions (>66.5%) due to its high hydrophilicity, while the hydrophobic BFI and ADP were primarily stored in cell walls and organelles. Hydroponic data revealed weak foliar uptake rates for BFI, ADP, and FPO (bioconcentration factors <1), but strong root uptake rates (bioconcentration factors >1). The translocation of these pesticides within the plant was limited (translation factor <1). BFI and ADP were taken up by roots through the apoplast pathway, while FPO was taken up via the symplastic pathway. This study enhances our understanding of pesticide residue formation in plants and provides insights for the safe application and risk assessment of BFI, ADP, and FPO.
plant_translocations.reference: Fang, N., Zhao, X., Li, Y., Luo, Y., Wang, X., He, H., ... & Jiang, J. (2023). Uptake, translocation and subcellular distribution of broflanilide, afidopyropen, and flupyradifurone in mustard (Brassica juncea). Journal of Hazardous Materials, 452, 131381.

method.Apply Location: The pesticides were applied either by foliar spray or root irrigation in hydroponic experiments.
method.Plant Grown Condition: The field trials were conducted at the Vegetable Science and Technology Demonstration Base located in Ningbo, Zhejiang Province, China (30.20° N, 121.07° E).
method.Chemical Preparation: The BFI suspension concentrate (SC, 100 g/L), ADP dispersible concentrate (DC, 50 g/L), and FPO soluble concentrate (SL, 17%) were provided by BASF and Bayer. Chromatography-grade acetonitrile and formic acid were used for analysis.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: According to the recommended dose, 1.2 mL of 100 g/L BFI SC, 1.2 mL of 50 g/L ADP DC, and 3 mL of 17% (170 g/L) FPO SL were separately applied once in different treatment plots. Control plots were treated with the same volume of water.
method.Other Information: The field trials were designed with treatment and control plots of 50 m2, each treatment comprising three replicate plots. Samples of leaves, stems, and roots (500 g) were collected from 12 points in the plots at 0, 1, 3, 7, 14, and 21 days after application. For root application, seedlings were transferred into nutrient solution with BFI, ADP, and FPO at a concentration of 0.1 mg/L. For foliar application, leaves were immersed in a solution containing 0.1 mg/L of each pesticide.
